review.title: Flip-Flop Sublinear Models for Graphs: Proof of Theorem 1
review.abstract: We prove that there is no class-dual for almost all sublinear models on graphs.
histories: Supplementary material for B. Jain. Flip-Flop Sublinear Models for Graphs, S+SSPR 2014
review.COMMENTS: Supplementary material for B. Jain. Flip-Flop Sublinear Models for Graphs, S+SSPR 2014

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: We prove the following result: Theorem 1. There is no class dual of a sublinear function with probability. The proof is based on material presented in [1] B. Jain. Flip-Flop Sublinear Models for Graphs, S + SSPR 2014. The content of [1] is not included in this essay. Section 1 introduces the formalism necessary to derive the proof. Section 2 provides auxiliary results. Finally, the proof of theorem 1 is presented in Section 3.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: Let G be a permutation group and XG be the quotient of the group action G on the matrix space X = Rn · n, where n is a number not smaller than the number of vertices of the largest graphs. With π we denote the natural projection from X to XG. For details, we refer to [1,2]. The stabilizer of w-X is a subgroup defined by Gw = {γ-G: γw = w}. If Gw is the trivial group, then every element of the orbit [w] has a trivial stabilizer. A diagram X should be regular if it is a representation of x-X with trivial stabilizer Gx.Support that f (X) = W · X + b is a sublinear function. A cross section with base point w-X is an injective map: XG → X-X-X = constellation (W).

references.title: Structure Spaces
author: B. Jain

references.title: Theory of convex polyhedral cones. Activity analysis of production and allocation
author: M. Gerstenhaber

referenceMentions.context: The content of [1] is not included in this contribution.

A Dirichlet domain is a convex polyhedral cone of dimension dim(X ) with the following properties: (1) Dw is well-defined, (2) x ∈ Dw iff (x,w) is an optimal alignment, (3) π(Dw) = XG, and (4) π is injective on the interior of Dw [2].
According to [3], Theorem 12, the intersection of two convex polyhedral cones is again a convex polyhedral cone.
